content.question: Zeb Lower Prices Same Prices Art Lower Prices <math alttext="$300" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>$</mi><mn>300</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>; <math alttext="$400" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>$</mi><mn>400</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> <math alttext="$600" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>$</mi><mn>600</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>; <math alttext="$200" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>$</mi><mn>200</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> Same Prices <math alttext="$100" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>$</mi><mn>100</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>; <math alttext="$700" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>$</mi><mn>700</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> <math alttext="$400" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>$</mi><mn>400</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>; <math alttext="$500" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>$</mi><mn>500</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> The above payoff matrix illustrates the daily profit for two restaurant owners, Art and Zeb. Each owner has the choice to lower prices for early bird customers or keep prices the same. The first entry in each cell indicates the profits for Art, and the second entry in each cell indicates the profits for Zeb. Each restaurant independently and simultaneously chooses its action and has complete information of the payoff matrix. Which of the following is a Nash equilibrium?

choices.label: Both Art and Zeb will lower prices.
Art will lower prices, and Zeb will charge the same prices.
Art will charge the same prices, and Zeb will lower prices.
Both Art and Zeb will charge the same prices.

content.answer: Both Art and Zeb will lower prices.

skill.text: Skill 2.C: Interpret a specific economic outcome using quantitative data or calculations.
